importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when former President Nicolas Sarkozy entered La Santé prison to begin serving a 5-year sentence for criminal conspiracy related to his 2007 campaign finance scheme.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which Sarkozy allegedly used his position as interior minister and presidential candidate to funnel Libyan funds into his 2007 campaign, forming the basis of the criminal conspiracy case.

keyTakeAways: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy began serving a 5-year prison sentence on October 21, 2025, making him the first ex-leader of modern France to be imprisoned.
Sarkozy was convicted of criminal conspiracy to finance his 2007 election campaign with funds from Libya, then led by Moammar Gadhafi.
He will serve his sentence in solitary confinement at the notorious La Santé prison in Paris.
Sarkozy's lawyers have filed for immediate release, arguing the conviction and incarceration are unjust, and he is being treated as a political victim of a 'plot' linked to Libya.
A significant public outpouring of support emerged in Paris, with supporters chanting 'Courage Nicolas' and displaying flags with messages of solidarity and belief in his innocence.

The case has sparked broader debate over judicial independence and political influence, especially given that France’s top magistrate warned that visits by political figures like President Emmanuel Macron could undermine the impartiality of the judiciary.
Sarkozy has publicly stated he is innocent and will fight the case, citing the need for truth to prevail, and plans to write a book about his prison experience.
He will receive one hour of outdoor time daily and three weekly family visits, and is restricted from contact with other inmates.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy entered La Santé prison in Paris on October 21, 2025, to begin serving a five-year sentence for criminal conspiracy related to using Libyan funds to finance his 2007 presidential campaign. This makes him the first former head of state in modern French history to be imprisoned. Sarkozy, 70, was convicted of orchestrating a scheme from 2005 to 2007 while serving as interior minister, leveraging his political position to funnel money from Libya, led by Moammar Gadhafi. He will be held in solitary confinement, with limited contact with others, and has filed for immediate release. His lawyers argue the conviction is politically motivated and unjust, claiming he is an innocent man targeted by a conspiracy. A massive public demonstration of support in Paris, including chants and flags, reflects deep national sentiment. The case has intensified debate about judicial independence, with France’s top magistrate warning that political figures like President Emmanuel Macron visiting Sarkozy could undermine the integrity of the justice system. Sarkozy has expressed defiance, stating he will fight the conviction and plans to write a book about his prison experience.
title: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy Begins 5-Year Prison Sentence for Campaign Finance Conspiracy
